text: If we are talking about how neighbourhood culture was back then…
…I can easily say that the connection and trust…
among the neighbours was very strong.
We are actually lucky.
We live in a place where neighbourhood culture…
…more or less still exists. We are lucky.
If you compare this place to large apartment complexes where people live collectively…
…we are in a small neighbourhood but even we complain about how good it used to be.
I can’t imagine what those people in huge places do.
Nobody knows anybody. But I still insist that…
…we are lucky because we live in an area…
…where neighbourhood culture is still alive.
We visit our neighbours and they visit us.
I can easily entrust my shop to a neighbour without hesitation.
I can leave my child at a neighbour’s house.
We are among the lucky people.
Classical Turkish music is playing.
We used to play a game which was called The Pin.
You needed an empty tin can and a ball to play.
The tin can is placed in the middle of the field with a rock on top of it to fix it in its place.
Then we tried to hit and knock it down by shooting the ball.
We also had another game which was called Snake.
You draw a long serpentine shape on the ground with a chalk and walked on it with small steps.
Everybody put down their initials on the parts they won.
And there was the game we played with "crown corks" or bottle caps.
We filled crown corks with a putty and played by sliding them.
We grew up on the street.
We really did grow up outside.
Sometimes I ask my mom, “How did you manage with three kids? I can’t handle one.”
“I can’t keep up with just one because I have to keep an eye on them all the time."
Back then, the external factors were not as bad as they are today.
We used to eat our food on the street.
We would get a half a loaf of bread filled with some food and...
…we fed ourselves while playing outside.
We used to stay outside and play until the very late hours.
Our parents didn’t think that something bad might happen…
…just because we were playing outside.
Our moms were outside too. They would lay a rug over the ground and…
…sit in front of the doors and talk. They would prepare food or tea and share with each other.
I don’t know, but these things have all disappeared.
We used to be very crowded.
There used to be large, empty areas for playing games.
Each neighbourhood had its own unique play area.
Whether it was greenery or an empty field, each neighbourhood had some sort of an area for kids to play.
The children playing on that field were safe and parents knew...
…where their children played and spent their time.
Unfortunately, we lost those playing areas.
When it was time to go home…
…our moms would call our names and we would hear them.
Perhaps there wasn’t this much noise and we could hear our moms.
Everybody was able to hear their mom’s voice from a distance and when we were called, we would go home.
There are one or two families left in our apartment building that I, my mom and my dad know.
The rest of the families in our apartment building have changed.
We have now new neighbours who are strangers.
My mom doesn’t know most of them.
As for us, other than occasional greetings with our neighbour on the ground storey…
…unfortunately, we don’t have any relationships with other families.
There is a change everywhere.
I spent my childhood in that garden.

-We’re going there now.
-Yes!
Here, we had many…
I can say that I grew up in this garden.
We had two places: One, the schoolyard, and two, this garden.
There were fruit trees in this garden.
There has been a walnut tree until very recently.
There was a thunderstorm some time ago.
A lightning bolt struck the big walnut tree and knocked it down.
Walnuts used to fall from the tree into the schoolyard.
The tree was in the garden but half of its branches used to extend into the schoolyard.
The students used to collect the walnuts that fell from the tree.
If we couldn’t get enough, we would move over to the garden….
…to get more walnuts.
I am getting acquainted with the place and collecting memories.
My husband has childhood memories from this neighbourhood.
This is a great place for me to take pictures.
There are many fruit trees.
It is great. Our balcony has a direct view of this garden.
That is one of the reasons we live here.
This garden is what makes me keep my flat here.
I have been living in this house for 30 years.
There is a chance that the government may expropriate…
…this parcel of land, including the house and the garden.
A building will be built here.
The nature here will disappear.
That’s a major problem. We were just talking about it.
I plan to start collecting signatures…

-…from the residents in the neighbourhood
-God willing!

-We'll sign without hesitation.
-Do you know what the project entails?

-Excuse me?
-Do you know what they will build?
Yes, I know. The land has been granted…

-…to the school board.
-Really?
So, we’ll lose this greenery.
Now, it looks that way.
I don’t know. We will prepare our petition of objection and submit it.
If our objection is sustained, we’ll save the land.
If not… I don’t know
Schools and education are important things but…
…I don’t know how feasible it is to have such a huge school…
…in the middle of the neighbourhood…
…if we consider it from the point of neighbourhood culture.
There are also many historical ruins here.
So I don’t understand…
how a construction permit can be granted.

-I hope everything turns out to be as you want.
-Thank you!

-We’ll just walk around a little. Goodbye.
-Thank you!
Go ahead!
Where is Hakan? Is he home??

-We won’t bother you too much?
-We’ll just take a quick tour.
We can also walk over to Sister Emine’s place.
This is quite a large area.
This is not a garden.
We can talk about how much this place is neglected but…
…this is the living space of these people.
As if we are in the middle of a forest in the centre of İstanbul.
Since our flat is on the top storey of that building…
…we wake up to this view every morning.
If anything happens to this place, and if a building is built here…
…we’ll put a “For Sale” sign on the window and leave the next day.
We yearn for nature and greenery.
I don’t think I can live in any other part of İstanbul.
Sometimes, my mom, my older sister or a relative stays with us.
And every time they say, “What kind of a house is this? Doesn’t this sound ever stop?”
“How can a place be like this?” We wake up to the sounds of roosters, chickens, birds, dogs.
My relatives always say, “What a great way to wake up.”
I really hope that nothing happens to this place. There are so many trees here, too.
These are all fruit-bearing trees.
How does someone have the heart to destroy these?
I used to walk all over those walls that you can see over there.
These walls have been under restoration for a long time.
We used to walk all over the wall from one end to the other.
Is it dangerous? Yes, it is.
But we were just kids.
Our skills may have developed also by playing on those walls.
We learned to be careful, to keep our balance, to anticipate danger and to take precautions.
We were really young kids when we used to play on the walls..
Eğrikapı [crooked gate] is one of the oldest quarters and has a crooked gate on the inside of the walls.
On our way back from visiting other neighbourhoods, when we reach the gates…
…my wife says, “We are back to our hometown.”
We feel estranged out of our neighbourhood but when we come back…

-…we feel relieved.
-We say, “That’s it!”
I feel like I am home when I see the walls on the way back.
If you dig the ground even just 10 centimeters at the bottom of the walls….
…it is almost certain that you will come across an object.
This is very interesting.
There used to be a lot of tourists visiting these parts back then.
It wasn’t like today. Nowadays, we get very few tourists.
We used to give tourists - you know how kids are…
Yes, it is something that I am not proud of but we were just kids and I can’t do anything about it now.
We gave them objects that we dug out…
What kind of objects were they? Maybe it was a small broken pipe.
I am not talking about things that can be considered as historical artifacts.
They were worthless little objects, such as a piece of a brick. They were things like that.
We would give those to the tourists and they would tip us, usually with small coins.
I sincerely hope that I didn’t cause any trouble for anyone who tried to take a piece back home.
But what is important is the fact that…
…you can still find things with historical significance…
…by digging the ground just 10 centimeters deep.
This is a very special and valuable land we live on.
But they are now working and there is support.
These walls have really lived through…
…some very strong earthquakes.
There are damaged parts.
But this damages is being repaired. That is very good.
They are being renovated.
If only they hadn’t used PVC frames, it would have been a lot better.
Let’s not pass without adding that.
